												Bus Simulator 16 was developed by still alive studios and published by Astragon. The game released on the 2nd March 2016 for a price of £18.99. In Bus Simulator 16, you are in charge of a bus company and must also drive around the bus collecting and dropping off people on various routes. During my hour of playing this game I had many ups and downs but the eventual ending was me stuck outside my bus and also stuck outside the depot with no way back.Positives:+ Good attempt at an entry level bus simulator – The game was designed to be a really good bus simulator but unfortunately falls quite short of that bar. The game feels more entry level but a good attempt at it.+  Steam Workshop – With steam workshop there will be mods to improve the game and adding own designs and busses.+ Tutorial – The tutorial is pretty good and I’m glad I did it. The amount of options and choices to the game is overbearing at times but I feel after an hour more confident  to try and drive a bus around.+ Multiplayer – This is a great add to the game, you can play online and manage routes together too, the only problem for me is that I lack friends with the game + Cops/Police – When I was idle at the station trying to figure out buttons and such a Police car went flying past me with the lights on. I found this so cool – however it may just be normal for most people.Negatives:- Floaty handling – The handling is not too good on this game and most the time I end up crashing and bashing when taking corners because the handling is too light.- Overwhelmed – There are just so many options, buttons, choices in which you must do and then to add to the top of all that the doors get jammed and the customers expect you to give them change from money which you can’t really make out.- Voice acting – If you can make it through the game without laughing at the terrible voice acting I commend you. I laughed quite often due to this fact.- Long loading times – It may just be my PC but I experienced agonising load times and very bad FPS.- Price – I feel the price should be halfed for the product because although you get a lot of content the quality is subpar.Unfortunately I felt this game had a lot of potential but the execution was pretty bad. I was hoping to finally get an Omni 2 experience on Steam but unfortunately this falls well below expectations and to me feels more of an entry product. I could only recommend this game to people with low expectations or standards (huehue). I played this game only for an hour but  I was left out in Sunny Springs in the rain, trapped from my bus and depot. Although I slate the game I enjoyed it for what it was but can’t possibly recommend the game at the current price point. I’m just glad the game never crashed on me because that would’ve been the icing on the cake.Score: Wait for a sale

												It's not every time I review a game, but I thought the need to review this game was high! Bus Simulator 16 is set in the town of Sunny Springs. Not only are you a bus driver, but you have to deal with a variety of events that happen around you! Driving the Bus The driving and stability of the bus is relatively easy. I'm currently using a Logitech G27 and I'm able to turn the steering wheel with no problem. However, I feel it can be quite stiff sometimes, but I'm sure this will be improved. The Passengers The passengers are amazing. You get a variety of different talks whilst driving your bus, from calling in sick to work, talking to fellow passengers etc. Other than when I give passengers their ticket, they say 'Thank you dear'. There are also other events including asking a passenger to move so you can close the doors, helping a wheelchair user onto the bus where you may need to get out of your seat and operate it manually or press a button at the cab, turning the air con/heating up or down to the passengers' wish or even dealing with drunk passengers. Pedestrians also relatively behave probably, I do get the occasional event where a passenger walks out in front of me at a crossing and your current drive would end immediately. There are also other events including fixing a jammed door, where you need to get out of your seat and manually close the door.  Graphics and Textures The graphics overall are pretty good. I've been hearing reports about the textures glitching out and turning to grey, however I have not been getting this problem. A feature I do like is when it's raining and the trees blow around. Unfortunately, when it is raining, you don't get any rain effects on the windscreen which was quite a disappointment. There are wipers, but there is no point in really using these. The AI Vehicles  The AI's behaviour in-game is very good, they will react to your indicators very well, like when you are pulling out of a bus stop, the car behind you will stop and let you out. There does seem to be a glitch where if you are sat in the cockpit, you won't be able to see the AI's lights (indicators, brake lights) but you will be able to see them from outside of the bus. This might explain to some people why they have been crashing into the back of AI cars, which I have done a couple of times.  AI will also behave probably when at traffic lights or junctions, so the developers have done a good job on coding the AI vehicles! The FPS I get in-game The FPS I get in-game is relatively good to keep it stable. I get around 40-50FPS overall when driving around or walking about in my office/garage. I have been looking at the reviews where some people have put a thumbs down because of the poor FPS they get in-game. I seem to be one of the lucky ones where I don't get any FPS problems and can play the game with no problem. However, I'm sure for those who are getting problems that there will be a patch relatively soon.  Overall Conclusion Overall, I believe Bus Simulator 16 is a great simulator and is much better than the previous bus simulator I had, which was OMSI 2, which had no end of glitches, crashes and bad in-game optimization etc. It's not every day you get a good Bus Simulator like this, probably one of the best to date. There may be a few glitches and bugs there and there, but let's be grateful that we have a good Bus Simulator!

												This is a very engaging and interesting game. You do more than just drive a bus - you also have to manage your own bus company, organise routes, deal with a variety of interesting situations (bus malfunctions, demanding passengers etc.), buy new buses, hire new drivers and so on. You get missions that help you unlock new features. You're never short of something to do.Bus Simulator 16 is made by the same people who developed Bus Simulator 2012, albeit with a different partner this time. I gave Bus Simulator 2012 a negative review, but I am happy to say that Bus Simulator 16 is a vast improvement - with one exception. Bus Simulator 2012 had awful frame rates, and unfortunately, so does Bus Simulator 2016 at present. I played on medium graphic settings with a pretty powerful computer, but found the gameplay very laggy and choppy, although just bearable. But I can play games like Euro Truck Simulator 2 or Train Simulator 2016 on high settings and have no FPS issues. So this is an area that needs work. And apparently, the developers are working on it, so hopefully performance will be much better soon.Some areas where Bus Simulator 2016 has improved on BS 2012 include keyboard steering (much, MUCH better, more like Euro Truck or American Truck Simulator steering now), AI traffic (much more sensible, accidents are usually due to your bad driving rather than their stupidity) and user-friendliness of the bus interior (no more password to enter, selling tickets is now much more efficiently handled). And of course, it introduces new things that were never seen in BS 2012, like the whole company management deal, missions and so on.Other than the need for performance optimisation, I have few complaints about this game. It is definitely the best bus simulator since OMSI 2, and has real potential to give the latter a serious run for its money. I am more than happy to recommend it.

What's to like about it?Bus Simulator 16 does exactly what it says in the title (that's always a good start)!  You start out with a simple route and basic vehicle, and you drive the route to collect fares, keep to a timetable, avoid accidents and (hopefully) make a profit.  When you have enough money, you can hire new drivers, buy new vehicles and drive new routes too.  This is a true simulator (not necessarily a 'fun' game) so will likely feel a bit dry for anyone looking for heaps of excitement!Whether you enjoy this simulator or not will come down to how well you treat the simulation.  If you ignore kerbs, corners and road positioning, you can hare from stop to stop and then it's done - boring.  However, if you play it as a trainee driver and use your mirrors to make perfect corners without clipping kerbs or hitting anything, (ie a bit of real-life stuff), then you will get much more challenge and simulation experience out of the game.  A wheel is recommended for the driving, and there is a full set of cockpit controls that you can click on in 3D view (a little like Train Simulator) or you can use button shortcuts instead.  I've driven several buses and coaches and I have to say the handling of the buses in-game isn't bad at all.  Some things are simulated perfectly, like mirrors and cornering (and reversing into your garage if you're feeling particularly cocky)!  This is as real as it gets and Bus Simulator 16 nails it perfectly.  Wheels on a bus or coach are a few feet behind the driver, so you must drive out into the junction straight before you can begin the steer.  Unlike a car, steering is not a single arm-wrench of the wheel and skid around that corner (pity)!  It's a nouanced set of movements (steer the front, straighten, steer again for rear wheels) that is difficult at first, but it's very true to life.  This is what the game does exceptionally well.  In reality, overall steering tends to be a little lighter and easier than is represented by the game, with only slight steer giving quite a turn, but the game wanted more steering than I would usually expect.  That could be that I don't have my in-game wheel settings balanced correctly though.Talking of wheels, many are supported but do check the forums as some people are having a few problems.  The newer Logitech 920 isn't currently working properly (the devs are looking at it).  As for older wheels like the Logitech G25 and 27, they do work after some fiddling.  It entails downloading Logitech's newest driver which no longer supports the G25/27 (nice one Logitech in forcing obsolescence in £200+ game controllers) and taking from the new drivers a DLL file and adding it to the game (all explained in the game forums), then reinstalling an older G25/27 supporting driver.  A nuisance, but doable.Anything not so good?The graphics are a bit basic for today's PCs, though they're not necessarily so important as the game mechanics are in a simulation title.  There is ONLY right-hand driving, which sucks for anyone in a left-hand drive country because this game actually makes quite a neat training aid.  The overall vehicle handling and steering response (particularly on straight roads) tends to be a little too heavy (steering of these vehicles is typically very light).  Oh, and there is no driver customisation which is a minor point, but being able to customise features, skin-tone and gender could have been a neat addition.  That's nit-picking though.Will you like it?If you're looking for a pure simulator title, then this is a good place to start.  It offers everything you need in setting up and driving basic bus routes and is actually good enough as a training aid for driving any long, non-articulated vehicle in managing corners well (all mirrors are recreated perfectly).  However, if you're looking for more of a 'game' experience, it might be a title you won't enjoy so much.

Embrace the MundaneIt's no secret that I've got a soft spot for what some might cruelly call the "mundane simulator"I've trucked and farmed my way through many a simulator title and I've loved them all.When I'm gaming I don't really discriminate between genres, being a gun toting super hero is fun but sometimes I just want to do something different, something normal that I'll probably never to get experience in my own "real life" something alternative but "mundane".I've come to terms with the fact that I'm firmly stuck in my rut in life, I'm never likely to be a truck driver or a farmer but these simulator games give you a chance to get a feeling of what it might be like, they give you a chance to experience a different life.It's the ultimate reality based escapism and it can definitely be a lot more fun than it sounds.So I've hauled cargo across Europe, I've trucked around the USA and I've farmed until the cows came home but I've never been a bus driver.Today we're going to fix that!Simple LifeLike a lot of jobs, on the surface it sounds pretty simple, I mean driving a bus, how hard could it be?You get to sit down all day and cruise around in a big circle, stopping every few minutes along the way.It doesn't sound too difficult does it?Your cargo even unloads itself!Ahhh to be a bus driver, that'd be a good life.With this mind I fired up Bus Simulator 16 ready for some hard core bus based business but I soon learned that being a bus driver isn't just about driving a bus, there's a wealth of bells and whistles that go along with the job that complicate things, which is just as well because it adds a little depth to what would other whys be a pretty simple driving game with some pretty bland scenery, but we'll get onto that later.The Wheels on the Bus...First the driving mechanic, a pretty important part of any game which involves driving and has the word "simulator" in the title.You'll have access to six different buses in the base game (who knows what DLC might bring) but for the most part this variety is purely cosmetic, the handling between each "flavour" of bus feels identical and the driving experience is more arcade than simulator.Speed and handling feel a little off (not that I've ever driven a bus, but I've been a passenger on a few) and the ride itself always feels disconnected from the road, it's too smooth and floaty, there's no rumble of an uneven road surface, no potholes to avoid (or deliberately drive over to annoy the passengers). The wheels on the bus might go round and round but there's no real sense that they're in contact with the road.This makes the driving part of Bus Simulator 16 a flat experience and that's a real shame.The Buttons on the BusWhilst the actual driving physics are pretty basic  there are still plenty of interactions with the vehicle to put some ticks in the simulation box.You get to turn the key to start your engine, flick the switches to put on the various lights both inside and outside the cab.There are buttons to raise and lower the bus and you even have a heater you can play with.The simulation doesn't restrict you to sitting in the driver seat either, if you feel the need you can always pull over and get out to stretch your legs (or stare unnervingly at your passengers who pretend not to notice).Tickets Please!Bus Simulator 16 isn't just about driving a bus around, there are plenty of other things you'll need to take care of too.Some passengers will need to buy a ticket from you, sounds straight forward right?but there are different ticket types, single, student, weekly, etc.  and do you think they'll have the correct change?Of course not!So you'll be working the ticket machine, selecting the ticket type and duration, printing out the tickets and calculating the correct change in your head all whilst you keep one eye on the clock.There's a time table to stick to and everyone hates it if the bus is late. Pesky PassengersIt's not just the ticket sales which slow down the turnaround time either, some passengers might require extra help, a person in a wheelchair for example will need you to vacate the drivers' seat and put down the ramp for them to board the bus, of course you'll need to stow the ramp away again before you head off.There's also a high probability that the disabled passenger will actually want to get off your bus again at some point, that'll mean you've got another ramp based delay to look forward to as you drive the route.The passengers don't even leave you alone when they've finally paid up and sat in their seats either. You'll be happily driving along, trying to make time back up on your route when you'll hear a moaning voice echo along the bus, "I'm too hot" or "It's too cold in here, can you do something about the temperature?".... ughhh, so now you're having to mess around with the air con. whilst keeping an eye on the sat nav. and another on the road. You wouldn't want to crash or run down a pedestrian, that might hurt your profit margin (and be bad for whoever you hit of course).Bus Mechanic 16So you herd the cattle (Sorry, passengers) onto the bus and manage not to freeze them, cook them or crash them into anything but there are still other things which can delay you.Even if the traffic is clear, the passengers are behaving and the traffic lights are green things can still go wrong.The bus itself can work against you, there can be mechanical issues which require your attention.For example the doors could become jammed and your cargo (sorry, passengers) are a fickle bunch and don't seem to like the thrill of being chauffeured around with the doors wide open, they worry about silly little things like falling to their death.You can pull over and fix these mechanical annoyances but it all takes time... time you'll need to make up on the road if you don't want to be late.Like the Back End of a Bus!Visually the game is a little disappointing, it's not ugly but the textures are fairly plain.Don't go into this expecting photo realism, or even  Truck Simulator quality graphics or you'll be disappointed by the view.Even at the highest settings the view distance on your rear view mirror is surprisingly low. You're constantly followed by what looks like really thick white fog pursuing you along the city streets, it's kinda scary really (Have you ever seen the Stephen King movie "The Mist"?).You're not just restricted to driving around one district either, as you progress in the game you'll be able to unlock 4 more to keep things interesting (the scary "mirror fog" will follow you to these districts too!)One Route to Rule Them AllIn addition to all the thrills of driving a big old bus around there's also a management simulation aspect to Bus Sim 16.Keeping your passengers happy and the fares rolling in is good for company profits and that's good for you because you own the company.You can tweak the look and colour of your buses and cover them in adverts to bring in some extra revenue.You'll be setting up bus routes and hiring drivers to trundle along them all in the name of profit, profit which you can then re-invest in more buses and more drivers.End of the LineBus Simulator 16 is an interesting title and whilst it can be fun there's no denying that it lacks a little polish.This is a niche game, it's not going to be for everyone, but if you're looking to try something a little different and think the life of a virtual bus driver might be for you then that's an itch this game will happily scratch.Like the review and want to see more? 												Bus Simulator 16 played using a Driving Force GT steeringwheel.BS16 is a surprise for me. I have little affinity with public transport if it isn't screaming along on a set of rails pulling a metric crapton of cargo-carriages. Another consideration is that I didn't think that coming to a stop at every lamppost would be fun.But BS16 takes the concept of driving something bulky through crowded streets and makes a potentially aggrivating activity a fun and enjoyable thing to do. The driving takes place in a colorful, full featured city that's brought alive by lots of traffic and pedastrians on the sidewalks. In my hours played already, I have never been in the 'last person on earth doing a public service job' situation many simulators tend to put the player in.The busses come in several flavors and are relatively easy to drive. There's little difference between them as they all have to same start up routine, the same transmission times, the same speeds, the same turn-radius and the same stupid ability to start driving backwards when you apply the brakes. (Errata: A setting in the options vaguely called 'drive aids' corrects that.)As a busdriver, you transport people along a busline that's initially set, but after a short while, you can erase that baby's first busline and construct your own lines, which you can also share online for other people to drive. When other people drive your shared line, you get paid.You sell tickets to people and have to give them correct change if they don't pay with ready money. Sadly, the amount of money they use to pay is not varied enough so that after a few stops you start giving people their change with your eyes closed. So, and idea that was initially fun, becomes a tedious chore due to how limited they made it.Passengers are interactive. A disabled person in wheelchair might need your help embarking or disembarking, an absent minded person might need to be made aware that you can't close the doors if he doesn't move further into the bus. The passengers have silly conversations that regularly make me laugh. One such an exchange really had me in stiches as a young woman rung up her mother on her cellphone to loudly exclaim that she was finally pregnant followed by 'No, I'm not at home, I'm in a bus!'.At first, I struggled with operating my bus. I kept clipping the curb, stepped on the brakes too heavy, stepped on the brakes too lightly, steered too little or steered too much and generally was allover the place. If the game wasn't so colorful, or if the game wasn't so alive with everything that's going on, I wouldn't have stuck with it as I did. After a while, it clicked and I was doing the rounds as if I had never done anything but drive busses all of my life. As I gained skill, my enjoyment of the game grew accordingly.As the manager of a bussing company, you can decorate your busses, get advertizement contracts, create buslines, hire and fire drivers and amass mountains of money. You advance your company's reach and reputation at a steady pace and you get a good feel of accomplishment out of it. Within the first few hours of play you're admiring your budding fleet of busses, see the map get filled by your buslines and smile as the game shows you a pop-up that someone has driven one of your shared lines which made a nice amount of cash.The traffic AI needs a good look-over however. It's downright more stupid than a bag of hammers in a glass-factory. When they do what they're supposed to do, it's fine and it makes the city-driving all the more realistic. But they more often do the stupid and annoy you by making sure that your bottomline is wrecked by financial setbacks you can't avoid. Pedastrians aren't much better, prone to start crossing the road when you're manouvring to rounda corner. That results in a 'big accident' that immedeately ends your run. When that happens near the end of a 30minute drive, there's little reason to smile. I don't mind failing because I made a mistake. I do mind failing because the AI is as stupid as the developer tasked with developing with the AI.Using a steeringwheel with forcefeedback and a 900degree turn is in my opinion a must. It really adds that extra like adding wheelturn resistance, which simulates that awesome 'I'm steering a huge and bulky vehicle' experience. The 900degrees wheelturn also removes the twitch-steering you get with the keyboard or a controller; making the turning more ponderous. The difference is really between night and day and heightens the immersion greatly.If the entire package wasn't so colorful, if the streets were scarcely populated, if the management layer would've been treadbare, if the passengers were badly animated cardboard cut outs, then the things like the busses all handling the same and the AI being terminally stupid would make BS16 just another 'german simulator with nothing to live for'.As it stands however, BS16 is saved by the attention to detail and many other things that really makes me feel that I'm a busdriver doing the rounds in a believable, albeit none existant, european city.Thumbs up then. If the developers keep working on this title and keep bettering it, then this game could become a benchmark for city-driving simulators. It's halfway to greatness already and I wholeheartedly recommend you this title.

												UPDATED (ALMOST 1year after release update)Sadly, not much changed in a year. Optimization is still requested by many which implies they havent dealt seriously with the problem. Only 2 DLC have been released and I see them as pure money grabber. They are not offering anything new than buses but those buses look exactly the same as the ones already ingame. The only difference is that they are branded MAN or Mercedes-Benz which (due to having to pay the right to the brands) are ridiculously expensive for the amount of content (and the usefulness of the said content has still to be proven).  In short, this game as still a long way to go. It does work but its not incredible performances and I'm afraid that those devs will follow the wrong path taken by Giants Software (farming simulator franchise) and will soon abandon this game to release a new one called Bus Simulator 18 which will be same engine, little difference in content but still priced the same. I hope I'm wrong, I cross my fingers for this... Still a positive review  but it could change after some time.ORIGINAL REVIEWAs promised, here is my review of the bus simulator  16. I played for nearly 8h and streamed it the whole time.While this is true the game is not optimized at all and this could make it impossible to play for some people, this game is far from the 45-50% rating it received on release. I'm glad it's back to 60% as I'm writing this review and I believe it could deserve to be a little higher like 70-75% because the game itself isn't bad. The devs just have a very hard time to optimize it and they are working on it very hard. I cross my fingers they release a fix quickly. But don't be fooled by those bad reviews. Almost none of those rate the game for what it is, they are just bad reviews of angry players not able to launch the game and not patient enough to give the devs a chance to release a fix.This game is not OMSI 2! If you seek for an incrediblely detailed bus simulator, don't buy. This game is more arcadish. If I had to compare it to other games, I would say it's like if OMSI 2 and Cities in Motion had a baby together. You have the management part of Cities in Motion (you create bus routes, assign drivers and busses to them, make sure they are giving positive income, etc). And with that you have the driving part of OMSI 2 (you drive buses, interact with passengers, deal with traffic, etc). You can interact with buttons in cockpit view. I was surprised there was so much to interact with in fact. So while it's not OMSI 2, it's still not a lazy game where you only accelerate/decelerate/left/right and nothing else. The driving is not the most realistic one but still very fun and it works very well with G27. Just a bit hard to set it up on first time but pretty fine after some gaming time.The multiplayer is a nice add considering lot of driving games never have one. Sadly, it's not a real multi. As you cannot see your drivers (AI) on the road, well you cannot see other players aswell in multi. It's more like if other players were replacing the AI so they are supposedly better drivers than AI but the mechanism behind is exactly the same. Very disappointed by this but I salute the effort. SCS (Euro and American Truck Simulator dev) never bothered trying to add a multi while players are hardly requesting it. StillAlive has work to do to catch on SCS but at least they tried. Let's give them a chance to improve. SCS didn't become a great truck sim developer in one day after all. ;)Only down side of the game are the graphics. They are not stunning at all and the game is more laggy than GTA V (I run it almost at ultra while I can barely run the bus sim at  medium with a poor 20FPS). Optimization is what hurts this game right now. As I said, I cross fingers the devs fix that soon. It's really annoying to have 30-45 second loading screen on launch and I'm lucky, some players must wait 4-5 minutes! So yes, if you are not patient to wait for a fix, don't buy or request a refund. But please, this game doesn't deserve so much bad reviews just because those devs are not experienced enough and have a little struggle optimizing their game. From a huge studio, I would have not forgiven such a mess with optimization, but for StillAlive, I'm ready to give them some time. I hope they will make good use of it.

												Plain and simple, this is the bus driving game I've been waiting for. What gets me excited about playing this game are the little things that do a lot to the immersion: Passengers running late, waiving at you in hopes you won't take off without them; traffic that doesn't constantly crash into you or each other but yield when you indicate that you are about to set off; jammed doors or passengers blocking doors from closing; handicapped passengers in need of a ramp; events like dynamic construction sites or an ambulance with wailing sirens, etc.. Further, Bus Simulator 16 gives you incentives to drive safely as you gain more reputation with your passengers when you do not drive like a maniac. You can if you want to, but it will hurt the rate of your progression (and your economy):Like Euro Truck Simulator 2, Bus Simulator 16 additionally has a management simulation mechanic which lets you buy new busses, hire drivers to generate additional revenue, customize your vehicles and even create all the routes on your own. These things (including new districts) are unlocked step by step as your reputation grows. If you have played other public transportation simulators before then you quickly learn the controls. The tutorial is also a good addition in explaining all the important elements. Handling and getting the bus to move is easier in Bus Simulator 16 than for example OMSI 2. Therefore, hardcore OMSI fans might get a little dissatisfied as mastering your vehicle is way simpler.The five available districs are rich in variety and the city is actually bigger than it seems when looking at the map. Unfortunately, the tool for creating routes does not give you any degree of freedom when it comes to choosing which road you want to use, resulting in odd and annoying routing in some cases.Further, and despite Bus Simulator 16 being neatly polished for a simulation game, it is quite heavy on performance. So if you do not have a very 'potent' computer you might get really poor framerates.Nonetheless, this game got me motivated and hooked right from the start. I hope for additional features for the route creation tool and performance improvements but apart from that I consider my 25 bucks well spent.

												I usually write an in-depth review on the games I play, but I'll write a quick "first-impression". The game is on sale at bundlestars and I figured why not.1) Graphics - their not terrible, but they could be better. The mirrors are no where near the quality of Euro Truck - they do provide extra info when driving (visually), but lack in representing it properly. I have NOT EXPERIENCED LAG ISSUES THUS FAR WITH FRAMERATES (which is good too). The mirrors are a big part of the experience (for me anyway). The right mirror needs a little more emphasis or maybe just fix it to the top right of the screen? Add an option for it? (Bang up job with the options in the game - turning cashier on and off is amazing). 2)Details - from cashier, to options, to heat, to bus tilting, to ramps, to people running late, to getting on and off your bus to fix doors etc... There here definitely. You can customize your bus and put adds on them for extra revenue. Annoyances (such as cashier-ing) can be turned off. It's only annoying as you cannot select individual buttons with the controller and must use the mouse. The dialogue is very cool and promotes positive citizens. Very nice to hear productive dialogue rather than dramatic. The turn signal even turns off after taking a turn. This is cool!3)Driving - No where near Euro Truck standards as it feels blocky. Driving is okay for the most part and the controls can be customized to your liking (which is a huge benefit). Lots of room for improvement here. Angles feel sharp and awkward at times, space margins don't feel right in First Person.4)Environment - It is pretty cool to drive a big vehicle in a busy city with pedestrians and cars. The crashes aren't the most details or greatest, but the game does note your driving habits (i.e speeding tickets or running red lights). Watching the emergency vehicles pop up makes me want an emergency driving simulator. I would love to be put in some tight situations... i.e certain stops have certain turns which make them challenging (but fun)!5) AI - The AI getting in and out of the bus is not smooth. There are a lot of waiting/pausing/collisions. Likewise with the traffic, cars will randomly stop in intersections or when you are around them. There isn't much a variable concerning how cars drive either than "stock" or very regular. Would be nice with some curveballs thrown in. 6) UI is quite friendly and easy to use. Bus routes cannot be set up manually as they are already fixed on the map. The player can see how much each route makes after a shift, but cannot see it from the main menu. I sank two hours into it instantly. I like the options given and the premise of the game, but I feel a lot more can be done to make this game better. Some will like it for what it is as there is not much competition regarding bus sims. Others will really hate the driving physics. I'll recommend it - with caution though! Do your homework as I think it's only worth a purchase on a major sale!

												At this moment i been playing the game for 3 hours. The first impressions are nice. You take over the bus company from a old man who is gonna retire. Up to you to build out the company and keep it healthy while you drive around in busses yourself as well.I really like how they put in little details with the passengers. In other bus simulators they are rather static and only react to certain things when you mess up. In Bus Simulator 16 your passengers talk with others so you can hear the conversations at times, they play around with their phone, checking for messages or playing games on it. But not for the whole ride, its not a animation that keeps playing till they leave the bus. Pedestrians also feel more alive, when they cross a street and a car is getting close they start to run. Emergency vehicles now also make their way trough the traffic, passing by when someone is standing still. A huge improvement over the others where they tend to stay behind cars and waiting in line till its their turn. They also drive trough the red light so you have make sure you let them go first when you hear the sirens.Another great thing are random events like maintenance to the road that makes you have to take a detour, problems with the bus you need to fix and you even get passengers in wheelchairs that you actually have to help with the ramp depending on what bus you are controlling. Don't forget this cause me and others already didn't notice them and drove off just to get the message i forgot a passenger.There are also some minor things. If you are a die hard simmer then this game might be a bit to arcady for you. Unlike it's competition you don't need to remember a lot of buttons and manage all aspects of the bus to make sure the temperature and such is good enough.This makes it easyer for beginners to get into or those who like driving a bus but find the competition to hard, but for those who are looking for the next big bus simulator this might be a disapointment.There are also some optimization issues going on, when you read the negative reviews you will see a few of them. I personally haven't had the game crash on me once, nor having any bug showing up ingame. Though the game could use some optimzation, i first thought it was my pc but reading the negative reviews it is the game appearantly. Though i lower my range of view and that helped alot with the fps drops.There are also long loading screens, however once it loaded the city it has loaded everything so when you unlocked the city you can drive around without any issues.There is also a multiplayer aspect though that means you can get a friend drive routes for your company and earn money for your company. The AI is good (for the most part), cars will most of the time let you pull out if you indicate and as others have said pedestrians actually wait for you if you are approaching a crossing at speed before crossing the road. 												I seriously can not understand where the hate this game is getting comes from. It does exactly what it says on the "box", and does it very well. While not a perfect game by any means, this is a great effort from a smaller company, that fills a niche I've personally desired for over 10 years.When I was a young lass, back in my high school days, I used to take the public bus to commute to school and back, and also to travel from place to place on my weekends. I spent hundreds of IRL hours on various models of IRL busses, and I always wanted to try driving one. This game finally allowed me to live my fantasy. I honestly never thought a company would ever bother to make a bus driving game, but Bus Simulator 16 actually goes above and beyond that, and includes management and a bit of strategy as well.In Bus Simulator 16, you'll assume the role of a man who has just started a bus company, and won a minor contract with the local city of Sunny Springs, and a few cheap models of busses to chose from. You'll start alone, with a limited amount of startup cash, with a small area available to you. Over time you'll prove to the city you can handle bigger contracts, which will give you access to more districts of the city, and more modern/expensive models of busses.Gameplay consists of 2 parts: driving your routes, and managing your company. Your company can be single player (offline) or co-op multiplayer (online), but if you choose to bring your company online it can not be undone. Managing your company consists of buying/maintaining busses, hiring/firing NPC (or other online players if you go multiplayer) drivers, and planning routes. You can paint your fleet various colors, and add advertisements to generate extra income.Driving is the heart of the game and you will need to drive each new route yourself first before you can assign that route to an NPC driver. You will be able to choose various models of busses to drive, including bendy (two car) busses. The in game tutorial is quick, easy to understand, and teaches you everything you need to know about driving. You will need to make all the stops on the route, while obaying traffic laws, keeping your schedule on time, charging passengers the correct fare, and making change, and accomidating any unexpected situation that may pop up.Driving the bus feels natural, and the controls are easy to pick up. The AI is dumb, and pedestrians will occasionaly step out in front of your rig, or change lanes into your path, but for the most part you can predict their behavior.  Weather, traffic jams, and various events (bouncing drunk passengers, unjamming stuck doors, extending the ramp for wheelchair bound passengers, etc.) will add variety to your routes.The dev is German, so the city/roads/laws are very european; As an American, this took some getting used to. In America, bus drivers expect you to have exact change for your fare, and carry no change. I don't know how they do things in Germany, but in this game you are expected to do math and count out correct change for everyone. This is the one part of the game that really sucks, but you'll soon memorize the appropriate amounts for each bill/fare and life will go on.The graphics are pretty bare bones, and honestly, what can you expect from a small dev making a game that will appeal to a niche group of players? I'm just happy this game got made at all. You will encounter some bugs here and there, but nothing that breaks the game or prevents you from running it smoothly (at least in my experience).Overall I would say if you're one of the people who is intrigued by the prospect of managing/driving for your own bus company, you should buy this game. It does what it sets out to do, and it works without crashing. What more can you ask for?

												It's no secret that I've got a soft spot for what some might cruelly call the "mundane simulator"I've trucked and farmed my way through many a simulator title and I've loved them all.When I'm gaming I don't really discriminate between genres, being a gun toting super hero is fun but sometimes I just want to do something different, something normal that I'll probably never to get experience in my own "real life" something alternative but "mundane".I've come to terms with the fact that I'm firmly stuck in my rut in life, I'm never likely to be a truck driver or a farmer but these simulator games give you a chance to get a feeling of what it might be like, they give you a chance to experience a different life.It's the ultimate reality based escapism and it can definitely be a lot more fun than it sounds.So I've hauled cargo across Europe, I've trucked around the USA and I've farmed until the cows came home but I've never been a bus driver.Today we're going to fix that!Simple LifeLike a lot of jobs, on the surface it sounds pretty simple, I mean driving a bus, how hard could it be?You get to sit down all day and cruise around in a big circle, stopping every few minutes along the way.It doesn't sound too difficult does it?Your cargo even unloads itself!Ahhh to be a bus driver, that'd be a good life.With this mind I fired up Bus Simulator 16 ready for some hard core bus based business but I soon learned that being a bus driver isn't just about driving a bus, there's a wealth of bells and whistles that go along with the job that complicate things, which is just as well because it adds a little depth to what would other whys be a pretty simple driving game with some pretty bland scenery, but we'll get onto that later.The Wheels on the Bus...First the driving mechanic, a pretty important part of any game which involves driving and has the word "simulator" in the title.You'll have access to six different buses in the base game (who knows what DLC might bring) but for the most part this variety is purely cosmetic, the handling between each "flavour" of bus feels identical and the driving experience is more arcade than simulator.Speed and handling feel a little off (not that I've ever driven a bus, but I've been a passenger on a few) and the ride itself always feels disconnected from the road, it's too smooth and floaty, there's no rumble of an uneven road surface, no potholes to avoid (or deliberately drive over to annoy the passengers). The wheels on the bus might go round and round but there's no real sense that they're in contact with the road.This makes the driving part of Bus Simulator 16 a flat experience and that's a real shame.The Buttons on the BusWhilst the actual driving physics are pretty basic there are still plenty of interactions with the vehicle to put some ticks in the simulation box.You get to turn the key to start your engine, flick the switches to put on the various lights both inside and outside the cab.There are buttons to raise and lower the bus and you even have a heater you can play with.The simulation doesn't restrict you to sitting in the driver seat either, if you feel the need you can always pull over and get out to stretch your legs (or stare unnervingly at your passengers who pretend not to notice).Tickets Please!Bus Simulator 16 isn't just about driving a bus around, there are plenty of other things you'll need to take care of too.Some passengers will need to buy a ticket from you, sounds straight forward right?but there are different ticket types, single, student, weekly, etc. and do you think they'll have the correct change?Of course not!So you'll be working the ticket machine, selecting the ticket type and duration, printing out the tickets and calculating the correct change in your head all whilst you keep one eye on the clock.There's a time table to stick to and everyone hates it if the bus is late.Pesky PassengersIt's not just the ticket sales which slow down the turnaround time either, some passengers might require extra help, a person in a wheelchair for example will need you to vacate the drivers' seat and put down the ramp for them to board the bus, of course you'll need to stow the ramp away again before you head off.There's also a high probability that the disabled passenger will actually want to get off your bus again at some point, that'll mean you've got another ramp based delay to look forward to as you drive the route.The passengers don't even leave you alone when they've finally paid up and sat in their seats either. You'll be happily driving along, trying to make time back up on your route when you'll hear a moaning voice echo along the bus, "I'm too hot" or "It's too cold in here, can you do something about the temperature?".... ughhh, so now you're having to mess around with the air con. whilst keeping an eye on the sat nav. and another on the road. You wouldn't want to crash or run down a pedestrian, that might hurt your profit margin (and be bad for whoever you hit of course).Bus Mechanic 16So you herd the cattle (Sorry, passengers) onto the bus and manage not to freeze them, cook them or crash them into anything but there are still other things which can delay you.Even if the traffic is clear, the passengers are behaving and the traffic lights are green things can still go wrong.The bus itself can work against you, there can be mechanical issues which require your attention.For example the doors could become jammed and your cargo (sorry, passengers) are a fickle bunch and don't seem to like the thrill of being chauffeured around with the doors wide open, they worry about silly little things like falling to their death.You can pull over and fix these mechanical annoyances but it all takes time... time you'll need to make up on the road if you don't want to be late.Like the Back End of a Bus!Visually the game is a little disappointing, it's not ugly but the textures are fairly plain.Don't go into this expecting photo realism, or even Truck Simulator quality graphics or you'll be disappointed by the view.Even at the highest settings the view distance on your rear view mirror is surprisingly low. You're constantly followed by what looks like really thick white fog pursuing you along the city streets, it's kinda scary really (Have you ever seen the Stephen King movie "The Mist"?).You're not just restricted to driving around one district either, as you progress in the game you'll be able to unlock 4 more to keep things interesting (the scary "mirror fog" will follow you to these districts too!)One Route to Rule Them AllIn addition to all the thrills of driving a big old bus around there's also a management simulation aspect to Bus Sim 16.Keeping your passengers happy and the fares rolling in is good for company profits and that's good for you because you own the company.You can tweak the look and colour of your buses and cover them in adverts to bring in some extra revenue.You'll be setting up bus routes and hiring drivers to trundle along them all in the name of profit, profit which you can then re-invest in more buses and more drivers.End of the LineBus Simulator 16 is an interesting title and whilst it can be fun there's no denying that it lacks a little polish.This is a niche game, it's not going to be for everyone, but if you're looking to try something a little different and think the life of a virtual bus driver might be for you then that's an itch this game will happily scratch.

experience in my own "real life" something alternative but "mundane".I've come to terms with the fact that I'm firmly stuck in my rut in life, I'm never likely to be a truck driver or a farmer but these simulator games give you a chance to get a feeling of what it might be like, they give you a chance to experience a different life.It's the ultimate reality based escapism and it can definitely be a lot more fun than it sounds.So I've hauled cargo across Europe, I've trucked around the USA and I've farmed until the cows came home but I've never been a bus driver.Today we're going to fix that!Simple LifeLike a lot of jobs, on the surface it sounds pretty simple, I mean driving a bus, how hard could it be?You get to sit down all day and cruise around in a big circle, stopping every few minutes along the way.It doesn't sound too difficult does it?Your cargo even unloads itself!Ahhh to be a bus driver, that'd be a good life.With this mind I fired up Bus Simulator 16 ready for some hard core bus based business but I soon learned that being a bus driver isn't just about driving a bus, there's a wealth of bells and whistles that go along with the job that complicate things, which is just as well because it adds a little depth to what would other whys be a pretty simple driving game with some pretty bland scenery, but we'll get onto that later.The Wheels on the Bus...First the driving mechanic, a pretty important part of any game which involves driving and has the word "simulator" in the title.You'll have access to six different buses in the base game (who knows what DLC might bring) but for the most part this variety is purely cosmetic, the handling between each "flavour" of bus feels identical and the driving experience is more arcade than simulator.Speed and handling feel a little off (not that I've ever driven a bus, but I've been a passenger on a few) and the ride itself always feels disconnected from the road, it's too smooth and floaty, there's no rumble of an uneven road surface, no potholes to avoid (or deliberately drive over to annoy the passengers). The wheels on the bus might go round and round but there's no real sense that they're in contact with the road.This makes the driving part of Bus Simulator 16 a flat experience and that's a real shame.The Buttons on the BusWhilst the actual driving physics are pretty basic there are still plenty of interactions with the vehicle to put some ticks in the simulation box.You get to turn the key to start your engine, flick the switches to put on the various lights both inside and outside the cab.There are buttons to raise and lower the bus and you even have a heater you can play with.The simulation doesn't restrict you to sitting in the driver seat either, if you feel the need you can always pull over and get out to stretch your legs (or stare unnervingly at your passengers who pretend not to notice).Tickets Please!Bus Simulator 16 isn't just about driving a bus around, there are plenty of other things you'll need to take care of too.Some passengers will need to buy a ticket from you, sounds straight forward right?but there are different ticket types, single, student, weekly, etc. and do you think they'll have the correct change?Of course not!So you'll be working the ticket machine, selecting the ticket type and duration, printing out the tickets and calculating the correct change in your head all whilst you keep one eye on the clock.There's a time table to stick to and everyone hates it if the bus is late.Pesky PassengersIt's not just the ticket sales which slow down the turnaround time either, some passengers might require extra help, a person in a wheelchair for example will need you to vacate the drivers' seat and put down the ramp for them to board the bus, of course you'll need to stow the ramp away again before you head off.There's also a high probability that the disabled passenger will actually want to get off your bus again at some point, that'll mean you've got another ramp based delay to look forward to as you drive the route.The passengers don't even leave you alone when they've finally paid up and sat in their seats either. You'll be happily driving along, trying to make time back up on your route when you'll hear a moaning voice echo along the bus, "I'm too hot" or "It's too cold in here, can you do something about the temperature?".... ughhh, so now you're having to mess around with the air con. whilst keeping an eye on the sat nav. and another on the road. You wouldn't want to crash or run down a pedestrian, that might hurt your profit margin (and be bad for whoever you hit of course).Bus Mechanic 16So you herd the cattle (Sorry, passengers) onto the bus and manage not to freeze them, cook them or crash them into anything but there are still other things which can delay you.Even if the traffic is clear, the passengers are behaving and the traffic lights are green things can still go wrong.The bus itself can work against you, there can be mechanical issues which require your attention.For example the doors could become jammed and your cargo (sorry, passengers) are a fickle bunch and don't seem to like the thrill of being chauffeured around with the doors wide open, they worry about silly little things like falling to their death.You can pull over and fix these mechanical annoyances but it all takes time... time you'll need to make up on the road if you don't want to be late.Like the Back End of a Bus!Visually the game is a little disappointing, it's not ugly but the textures are fairly plain.Don't go into this expecting photo realism, or even Truck Simulator quality graphics or you'll be disappointed by the view.Even at the highest settings the view distance on your rear view mirror is surprisingly low. You're constantly followed by what looks like really thick white fog pursuing you along the city streets, it's kinda scary really (Have you ever seen the Stephen King movie "The Mist"?).You're not just restricted to driving around one district either, as you progress in the game you'll be able to unlock 4 more to keep things interesting (the scary "mirror fog" will follow you to these districts too!)One Route to Rule Them AllIn addition to all the thrills of driving a big old bus around there's also a management simulation aspect to Bus Sim 16.Keeping your passengers happy and the fares rolling in is good for company profits and that's good for you because you own the company.You can tweak the look and colour of your buses and cover them in adverts to bring in some extra revenue.You'll be setting up bus routes and hiring drivers to trundle along them all in the name of profit, profit which you can then re-invest in more buses and more drivers.End of the LineBus Simulator 16 is an interesting title and whilst it can be fun there's no denying that it lacks a little polish.This is a niche game, it's not going to be for everyone, but if you're looking to try something a little different and think the life of a virtual bus driver might be for you then that's an itch this game will happily scratch.

												Hello My name is Mike and I am aka Sim UK.  I have been running a Bus Sim 16 Let's Play since this game came out.  I have reviewed and updated the Youtube community on all patches and Updates and will continue to do so:https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL-Al6rzTlW-h2Y7i_6ikKp1GXWdbvnWf-I am a big fan of OMSI2 but not of the bugs and issues that come as part of it.  I was hoping that Bus Sim 16 was going to be the solution to the OMSI problem but it isnt really the same kind of game, let me explain;OMSI is a tremendously accurate and capable bus simulator with modding tools which allow the community to enhance update and develop copius amounts of top quality add-ons, which is why this game is still being played and sold today.Bus Simulator 16, despite its title, is not a simulator.  I think the best way to decribe it is that it is a casual Simulator, a new breed of simulator that is in part an arcade game.  Because of the title many people bought this game expecting a simulated experience and were bitterly dissapointed as a result, as was I.Over time I have grown to like this game a great deal, IF the developers enable players to start modding (PROPERLY and FULLY) new buses and most importantly maps, then this game will have a long an prosperous life, if they don't then this is a fun to play one off that will just dissapear in the next year or two.Pros-----Nice enough graphics and gameplay.Works out of the box.Lots of missions to keep you gong for a while at least.Fun.If £10 this is a bargain.  £15 OK but better to wait. £20 Nope, too much :(Cons====There are numerous graphic issues.AI is poor but funtional most of the time.Very poor modding tools, so limited they are useless.1 map only and no way to create new ones.Poor optimisation!  I have a decent PC and have no issues but there are plenty who do.UPdates are usually poor, no content and include no real imporvement.Overall this is a fun game to play, its easy to learn and doesnt get boring (somehow?)RATING (6.5/10) Would be more if modding tools were made available.

												I cannot understand the many negative comments on this game. Im not sure what people expect from a relatively cheap, non-AAA game. Im playing on the 'test' performance version and it runs well and have not had any crashes thusfar and I get the feeling many of the earlier gripes have been attended to. PROs:+ It looks decent enough.+ The performance patch has made the game a lot better.+ Very good G27 steering wheel support, ready to play when I plugged it in.  Not even Project Cars or Assetto did that, and it took me an afternoon to set up my wheel on OMSI 2! + Very accesible and super intuitive user interface+ Ability to run your own company, hire and fire drivers, create  lines: these add to the fun and  playability.  + Has an easy to use, uncomplicated cashier system with English speaking Passengers+ Driving is not as realistic as OMSI 2 but, it definitely is not  completely arcade. Realism is at the very worst, passable.+ Its surprisingly stable and bug free. CONS :- Single map limits the game somewhat, making it easy to burn out on the gameplay quicker than Id like.- No force feedback for engine vibration or terrain, makes the driving experience feel 'floaty'.-Workshop items are a little sparse. I think if the developers continue to work on the realism and physics of the gameplay and continue to implement suggesstions made by the community, as they have been doing, this game will hands down beat the competition.If you are looking for a starter Bus SImulator - this is the better choice. If you want an excellent, hightly realistic driving experience, but dont mind wrestling with a horribly quirky user interface,  dealing with lots of German and have the patience to figure out a hard to access, complicated routing system, get OMSI.Dont hate me, but I have been playing this as my bus simulator of choice. It may not be as realistic as it gets, but its great fun.

												can I recommend this Bus simulator, well YES and NO.And let me start by saying that if you consider buying this or some other bus simulator then I would highly recommend you to buy bus and cable car simulator instead..Well let me review Bus simulator 16 first, it is actual quite good and have allot of good things to offer for a low price.First of all the graphics are not 2016 std. and look a bit old, though it do not matter that much since where are here to drive a bus right ? ;-)Well the city itself is create well and there is a mix of both ordinary recidential and more dence areas with sky scrapers and conventions centers, and that make it interesting to driver from a-z.The streets are filled with cars and pedestrians and sometimes even emergency vehicles that you need to let pass.It also happen that cars drive out in front of you or pedestrians almost walk on the street in front of you, so you need to keep your eyes open. Well I like these small events now and then it make the game interesting.One other things that make the game interesting is the ability to exit your seat and walk arround in the world and solve small problems. For example a drunk guy enters the bus so you have to get up and ask him to leave.And one in a while you also have to help handicapped people in/out of the bus by exit the bus and extending the ramp ;-)The all new "run a bus business" feature is nice, and you can even compare how well you are doing to other players though some have kind of unrealistic billion usd scores.Anyway you can also invite your friends to come and drive a trip in your bus and follow one of your routes that you create and it is kind of nice i think.It is also possible to paint your car and stick commercials on it to earn a little more, though It not really where that important to me.Well the bus driving experience is kind of okay. The feeling of sitting in the seat and driving I would say is realistic and the bus feel big ect. And you can also press various keys and sell tickets ect. The bus is also well made and in general give a good impression.However the controls of the game are not that facinating.First of all the game do not yet support Trackir ( the dev. wrote on the forum that they consider implementing it ).So many people are now forced to use the mouse to look arround or setup X and Y key on their wheel to look left and right. No matter what it is not the same as trackir and free look with the mouse. ALso I really miss the ability to look 90 degrees left and right in the bus since it is hard to see the trafic when at a T crossing and only can look 75-80 degrees left and right.Well all in all I think price level is good fair price for the product. The game is not bad, and have many nice features ( like you can hear small talk in the bus, such as boss i cant go to work today ).Also the get in and get out of the bus by passengers work pretty good, and you often fill your bus pretty good with passengers.I also like that sometimes there are events such as holliday where there are tons of passengers waiting for a ride.The game it self work in such a way you unlock features by driving from a-b.. in about 3 hour of gameplay I am level 10-11 and have unlocked the biggest bus in the game and half of the map.To unlock more I need to play the game and get xp, but I can also solve some goals ( such as having 2 bus stops in each unlocked zone ect ). All in all not a bad game but it do feel a bit like an arcade bus simulator, so I really prefer the older game named "Bus and cablecar simulator" since the busses are a little more realistisc, and the game experience is just a bit more fun and realistic.
